column4: i belive -Y is faster but less secure. used on local/trusted lans.. (or so i recall in some ssh docs)
when in doubt - read the ssh docs i guess. :)
you've seen the size of that monster
-Y      Enables trusted X11 forwarding.       -X      Enables X11 forwarding.
from the MAN page.. seemns -Y is more secure
i got confused it said that -x disabled  forwarding.. -X enables it.. :) hard to tell the diff  from x and X in my console font..
I have, RTM but I've stated before that I have this condition called manualitis, where large manuals make me his my head on my keyboard
the locate database has a setting file that dictates  what filesystems it scans.
thats normally a feature of the vnc CLIENT - from what ive seen. some can doit. some cant
got a name of one that does, i use Terminal Client
under windows 'ultravnc' :) other then that. I dont use the clients much under linux.
gnome and kde both have their own client. that has more features then the normal vncviewer app.
what do you use for remote?
i only use vnc under windows to get to the vncserver on the linux box. using the vnc4server on linux.
many support a 'whatever --replace' option, or depending on how it got launched, you can kill it from a terminal, and run another.
ive seen some that come with menu items to launch alternative window managers.. depends on your needs.
